title: Malaysian giant turtle
text:
The Malaysian giant turtle or Bornean river turtle ("Orlitia borneensis") is a species of <a href="turtle">turtle</a> in the family <a href="Bataguridae">Bataguridae</a>. It is <a href="monotypic">monotypic</a> within the <a href="genus">genus</a> Orlitia. It is found in <a href="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> and <a href="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>.
This species is the largest freshwater turtle in <a href="Southeast%20Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, reaching a maximum length of 80 cm (31 inches) and a maximum weight of up to 50 kg (110 pounds). It inhabits large <a href="Lake">lakes</a>, <a href="Swamp">swamps</a>, and slow-flowing <a href="River">rivers</a>. This mainly <a href="Piscivore">piscivorous</a> (fish-eating) species has a dark brown or black <a href="carapace">carapace</a> which is smooth and oval in shape and a pale yellowish-brown to off-white <a href="plastron">plastron</a>. The head is powerful, with strong jaws and a slightly projecting snout, and the heads of adults are uniformly colored dark brown to black whereas juveniles are dark mottled with a pale line extending from the mouth to the back of the head. It occasionally takes fallen <a href="fruit">fruit</a> and may consume and other available <a href="vertebrate">vertebrate</a>. This species is exported in huge amounts from <a href="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> for its highly prized flesh and despite its rarity it is not protected in <a href="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>. <a href="Habitat%20destruction">Habitat destruction</a> for <a href="palm%20oil">palm oil</a> plantations and <a href="poaching">poaching</a> for the <a href="Traditional%20Chinese%20medicine">Chinese medicinal</a> trade have also contributed to its <a href="Critically%20endangered">Critically Endangered</a> IUCN status.
